metadata.titleEn: Dataset of global urbanization projections under the shared socioeconomic pathways (2015-2100) V1.0
metadata.description: This dataset includes information on the level of urbanization (measured by the portion of urban population relative to total population) for approximately 200 countries and regions under different shared Socioeconomic pathways around the world from 2015 to 2100. The production process of this dataset mainly includes : (1) Based on the urbanization level dataset of the World Urbanization Prospects 2018 Revision (1950-2010) and the World Bank (1960-2019),  logistic regression models for different countries are established to calculate the speed of urbanization level. (2) Using the different speed of urbanization in reference countries and regions to further estimate the development trend of urbanization. The dataset is expected to be widely used in future socio-economic development and climate change research. The detailed procedure for generating this dataset can be found in Chen, S., Huang, Q., Muttarak, R., Fang, J., Liu, T., Heng, C., Liu, Z., Zhu, L. (2022). Updating global urbanization projections under the Shared Socioeconomic Pathways. Scientific Data, 9. 137.
metadata.instructions:
File name: The file is saved in . csv and. xls format.The name of the file as "SSPscene _XX (_SD)". Among them, "the SSPscene" on behalf of the Shared Socialeconomic path."XX" on behalf of the dataset: WB folder is based on the annual historical data from the World Bank, WUP2018 folder is based on the historical urbanization level database from the World Urbanization Prospects. "SD" on behalf of uncertainty. For example, ssp1_WB.csv represents the urbanization rate of each country and region in 2015-2100 under the SSP1 scenario calculated based on the World Bank 's historical urbanization rate dataset. The file "the 100% urbanization level countries and areas_XX " contains information on countries that achieved 100 % urbanization in 2015. Because these countries have reached 100% urbanization rate in 2015, so there is no further estimate the urbanization rate of the future. At the same time, the files also include historical data so far in 1960. 
Method of data read: users can use the ESRI ArcGIS , Excel or other related softwares to read data.

literatureList.titleEn: Updating global urbanization projections under the Shared Socioeconomic Pathways

background: Urbanization level is an important indicator of socioeconomic development, and projecting its dynamics is fundamental for studies related to global socioeconomic and climate change.
research objective: This paper aims to update the projections of global urbanization from 2015 to 2100 under the Shared Socioeconomic Pathways by using the logistic fitting model and iteratively identifying reference countries.
challenges: However, this method contains several issues. First the previous global projections did not develop country-specific models to estimate urbanization level. The estimated values based on such global uniform models may yield inaccurate results when compared to the historical urbanization level. Second, the coefficients in the established model and the identified reference countries for simulating future urbanization level were not updated in an iterative and dynamic fashion. For example, Jiang and O’Neill estimated the future urbanization level by adjusting the speed of urbanization derived from reference countries every 30 years. However, urbanization is dynamic: some countries may change from developing to developed in less than 30 years. Accordingly, the coefficients and reference countries should be updated more frequently. Third, some projections used the logistic fitting model to estimate the urbanization level. Such model assumes that a country’s urbanization level follows an S-shape curve and reaches a saturation stage (usually set to 80%) at which the urbanization level ceases to increase. However, previous studies have found that a country’s urbanization level will continue to increase after reaching the saturation stage, especially in the context of globalization and global change. Dynamically adjusting the saturation value to accurately simulate the changes in urbanization level after the saturation stage is thus a challenge. Fourth, previous studies did not provide a range of uncertainty. In long-term projections, the urbanization level is commonly used as an input in integrated assessment models or coupled earth system models. Therefore, its uncertainty can provide key information for the uncertainty and robustness of the results of these coupled models.
methods: We first establish a logistic model to fit the changes in urbanization level from 1950 to 2010, and then evaluate its performance. We provide two projections generated from two data sources (i.e., WUP 2018 and World Bank (WB)) with time steps of 5 years and 1 year, respectively. The two projections are compared, and the projected values based on the WB data 2010–2018 are validated with the historical values.
dataset: Based on historical urbanization level database from the World Urbanization Prospects, projected urbanization levels and uncertainties are provided for 204 countries and areas every five years. The 2010–2100 year-by-year projected urbanization levels and uncertainties based on the annual historical data from the World Bank (WB) for 188 of countries and areas are also provided.
findings: The results show that the absolute differences between our WUP-based predictions and the true values are less than 1% at the global scale, and the absolute differences between the WB-based predictions and the true values are less than 1.3% in 2015. This also demonstrates that our study reliably portrays the level of urbanization at the global.

Verification.Question: Are there challenges associated with the static nature of coefficients and reference countries in the logistic fitting model for urbanization projections?

Disjunctive.Question: Is the logistic regression model, iterative identification of reference countries, or dynamic saturation value adjustment more critical for projecting urbanization levels accurately?
Disjunctive.Answer: iterative identification of reference countries and dynamic saturation value adjustment

Disjunctive.Question: Do challenges in urbanization level projections arise more from the lack of country-specific models, the need for frequent updates, or the absence of uncertainty ranges?
Disjunctive.Answer: lack of country-specific models and the need for frequent updates

Concept Completion.Question: What are the key challenges in using logistic regression models to project future urbanization levels under different Shared Socioeconomic Pathways?
Where can data for historical urbanization levels be sourced for constructing logistic models to predict urbanization trends?
When should the coefficients and reference countries in urbanization projection models be updated to accurately reflect changes in urbanization dynamics?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used for estimating urbanization levels globally from historical data?
Example.Answer: One example of a data collection method is the use of logistic regression models based on historical urbanization level databases, such as the World Urbanization Prospects and World Bank urbanization rate datasets. These models are used to fit changes in urbanization level across different countries and predict future trends.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset that includes projected urbanization levels and uncertainties for different countries?
Example.Answer: An example of such a dataset is one that provides projected urbanization levels and uncertainties for 204 countries and areas every five years, based on historical data from the World Urbanization Prospects. Additionally, it includes year-by-year projections from 2010 to 2100 based on annual historical data from the World Bank for 188 countries and areas.

Feature Specification.Question: What specific challenges are associated with dynamically adjusting saturation values in urbanization projections?
Feature Specification.Answer: 80% saturation point, ongoing increases in urbanization beyond saturation

Quantification.Question: How many countries and areas are included in the projected urbanization levels dataset for the period 2010–2100?
What is the time step used in one of the urbanization projections based on the data sources provided?
What is the range of years covered by the global urbanization projections dataset under different Shared Socioeconomic Pathways?

Definition.Question: What does 'Shared Socioeconomic Pathways' (SSPs) imply in urbanization projections?
Definition.Answer: Shared Socioeconomic Pathways (SSPs) imply a set of scenarios used to explore future changes in urbanization levels under different socioeconomic conditions, helping to assess potential impacts on climate and socioeconomic development.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'uncertainties in urbanization projections'?
Definition.Answer: Uncertainties in urbanization projections refer to the variability or range of possible outcomes in projected urbanization levels, which can affect the robustness and reliability of models used in socioeconomic and climate change research.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods using logistic regression models for urbanization projections compare to using other statistical models in terms of accuracy and adaptability to historical data?
Comparison.Answer: The logistic regression model is used to establish changes in urbanization levels and is evaluated for its performance. It fits historical data from 1950 to 2010 and provides projections with low absolute differences compared to true values, demonstrating its reliability in portraying urbanization levels globally. The model assumes an S-shape curve and needs dynamic adjustments, especially at the saturation stage, to improve adaptability and accuracy.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in uncertainty estimation between projections based on the World Urbanization Prospects data and those based on the World Bank data?
Comparison.Answer: Projections based on the World Urbanization Prospects data and World Bank data show differences in uncertainty estimation, with the former providing data every five years and the latter annually. The absolute differences in predictions are less than 1% and 1.3%, respectively, indicating a slight variance in uncertainty and accuracy between the two data sources, with the World Bank data offering more frequent updates.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the challenges faced by urbanization level projections differ when using global uniform models versus country-specific models?
Comparison.Answer: Global uniform models face issues with accuracy when estimating country-specific urbanization levels, potentially leading to inaccurate results. Country-specific models aim to address these by developing tailored approaches for individual countries, allowing for dynamic updates of coefficients and reference countries, thereby improving the accuracy and relevance of projections in rapidly changing socioeconomic contexts.

Interpretation.Question: How can logistic regression models be adapted or refined to account for dynamic changes in urbanization levels across different countries over extended time periods?
Interpretation.Answer: A logistic model can be established to fit changes in urbanization levels, and its performance can be evaluated by comparing projections generated from different data sources such as WUP 2018 and the World Bank. The model should be iteratively updated to reflect frequent changes in urbanization dynamics, accounting for country-specific developments beyond traditional saturation assumptions.

Interpretation.Question: What are the implications of using historical urbanization data from sources like the World Urbanization Prospects and World Bank for accurately projecting future urbanization trends?
Interpretation.Answer: Using historical urbanization data from sources like the World Urbanization Prospects and World Bank allows for the development of projections that are validated against historical values, ensuring that the predicted urbanization levels closely match true values, with reported differences of less than 1% and 1.3% respectively at a global scale.

Interpretation.Question: How can the uncertainty in long-term urbanization projections be quantified and incorporated into integrated assessment models or coupled earth system models?
Interpretation.Answer: Uncertainty in long-term urbanization projections can be quantified by providing projected urbanization levels and associated uncertainties for countries and areas over time. This information can then be utilized as input in integrated assessment models or coupled earth system models, offering key insights into the uncertainty and robustness of these models' results.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors lead to the need for updating reference countries more frequently in urbanization projections?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Urbanization is dynamic, and some countries may change from developing to developed in less than 30 years. This necessitates frequent updates to the coefficients and reference countries to accurately simulate future urbanization levels.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it crucial to dynamically adjust the saturation value in logistic models for projecting urbanization levels?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Previous studies found that a country's urbanization level can continue increasing after reaching a saturation stage due to globalization and global change. Therefore, dynamically adjusting the saturation value is essential to accurately simulate urbanization changes beyond the saturation point.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What motivates the inclusion of uncertainty ranges in long-term urbanization projections?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Including uncertainty ranges provides key information for assessing the robustness and uncertainty of integrated assessment models or coupled earth system models, which often use urbanization level as an input.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of incorporating both WUP 2018 and World Bank data into the urbanization projections?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Incorporating both WUP 2018 and World Bank data allows for a comparison of projections, which can help validate the projected values against historical data. This approach can enhance the reliability of the urbanization projections by minimizing discrepancies between different data sources, with differences being less than 1% at the global scale and less than 1.3% for WB data in 2015.

Causal Consequence.Question: What might be the effects of dynamically adjusting saturation values in logistic models on simulating urbanization levels?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Dynamically adjusting saturation values in logistic models could lead to more accurate simulations of urbanization levels, especially after reaching the traditional saturation stage. This adjustment addresses the challenge of continued urbanization growth in the context of globalization, potentially improving the model's ability to reflect real-world changes beyond assumed saturation points.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives of providing a range of uncertainty in long-term urbanization level projections, especially in the context of integrated assessment models or coupled earth system models?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective of providing a range of uncertainty is to offer key information for understanding the uncertainty and robustness of results from integrated assessment models and coupled earth system models, which often use urbanization level as an input.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in establishing a logistic regression model to fit changes in global urbanization levels from historical data sources?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: A logistic regression model is established by first utilizing historical urbanization data from sources such as the World Urbanization Prospects and World Bank. The model fits urbanization changes from 1950 to 2010 and evaluates its performance by comparing projections from two data sources, with time steps of 5 years and 1 year, respectively.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can one dynamically adjust saturation values in logistic models to accurately simulate urbanization levels beyond the saturation stage?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To dynamically adjust saturation values, one must consider that urbanization levels can continue to rise after reaching an initial saturation stage. This involves updating model coefficients and reference countries iteratively and more frequently than every 30 years, as urbanization can change rapidly in less than 30 years due to factors like globalization.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies are applied to validate the projected urbanization levels against historical values to ensure accuracy?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Projected urbanization levels are validated by comparing them to historical data from the World Bank for the years 2010-2018. The validation process involves assessing the absolute differences between projected values and true values, ensuring that these differences are minimal, such as being less than 1% at the global scale.

Enablement.Question: What data collection techniques have enabled the accurate projection of urbanization levels under various socioeconomic pathways?
Enablement.Answer: The techniques involve establishing logistic regression models based on historical urbanization data from sources like the World Urbanization Prospects and the World Bank. These models calculate urbanization rates and predict future trends by iteratively updating coefficients and reference countries.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies are employed to address the uncertainty in long-term urbanization projections?
Enablement.Answer: The methodologies include providing multiple projections from different data sources (e.g., WUP and World Bank) and comparing these against historical values. This dual approach helps quantify uncertainties and enhance the robustness of models used in integrated assessment and earth system models.

Expectation.Question: Why might a dataset on urbanization levels under different socioeconomic pathways face challenges in accurately reflecting historical urbanization trends?
Expectation.Answer: The challenges stem from the lack of country-specific models in previous global projections, which may result in inaccurate estimates when compared to historical urbanization levels. Additionally, the coefficients and reference countries used in models need to be updated more frequently to reflect the dynamic nature of urbanization.

Expectation.Question: What factors could contribute to the difficulty in projecting urbanization levels beyond a saturation stage in a dataset using logistic fitting models?
Expectation.Answer: The logistic fitting model assumes that a country's urbanization level follows an S-shape curve and reaches a saturation stage, typically set at 80%. However, studies have shown that urbanization can continue to increase due to globalization and other factors, making it challenging to dynamically adjust the saturation value accurately in projections.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be a necessity to provide a range of uncertainty in urbanization level projections within a dataset?
Expectation.Answer: In long-term projections, urbanization levels are often used as inputs in integrated assessment models or coupled earth system models. Providing a range of uncertainty is crucial as it offers key information regarding the uncertainty and robustness of the results produced by these coupled models.

Judgmental.Question: How might the iterative identification of reference countries enhance the accuracy and reliability of urbanization projections?
Judgmental.Answer: The iterative identification of reference countries allows for more dynamic and frequent updates to the model, reflecting the fast-paced changes in certain countries' development status from developing to developed. This approach addresses the challenge of using outdated coefficients and reference countries which can lead to inaccurate projections.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges in adjusting the saturation value dynamically to simulate changes in urbanization level after reaching typical saturation stages?
Judgmental.Answer: Adjusting the saturation value dynamically is challenging because traditional models assume a fixed saturation stage, typically at 80%. However, evidence suggests that urbanization can continue beyond this stage, particularly in the context of globalization. Accurately simulating these changes requires overcoming the assumption of a static saturation point and addressing the variability introduced by global influences.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways could providing a range of uncertainty benefit the long-term projections of urbanization levels used in integrated assessment models?
Judgmental.Answer: Providing a range of uncertainty in urbanization projections can enhance the robustness and reliability of integrated assessment models or coupled earth system models, as it offers key information about potential variability and risks. This can help stakeholders better understand and prepare for potential outcomes and the implications of urbanization on socioeconomic and climate change scenarios.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how a dataset could accurately predict urbanization levels over such a long period given the dynamic nature of socioeconomic factors.
Assertion.Answer: The dataset uses a logistic regression model to fit urbanization trends from historical data and iteratively updates reference countries to reflect changes in socioeconomic conditions, allowing for more accurate long-term projections.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about how data collection methods can address the inherent uncertainties in projecting global urbanization rates.
Assertion.Answer: The method provides projections from two different data sources with varying time steps and validates projections against historical data, which helps estimate uncertainties and improve the robustness of the dataset.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how a dataset can adjust to changes in the urbanization saturation stage, especially given global changes.
Assertion.Answer: The dataset dynamically adjusts the saturation value within the logistic model to simulate urbanization changes beyond the conventional saturation stage, accounting for ongoing global changes.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the methods used to project urbanization levels from historical data and explain how these methods address the challenges of projecting future urbanization trends.
Request/Directive.Answer: The projection of urbanization levels employs a logistic model that fits changes in urbanization from 1950 to 2010. This method addresses challenges by iteratively updating coefficients and reference countries to reflect dynamic changes and by dynamically adjusting the saturation value to simulate changes beyond typical saturation stages. Two projections are generated from WUP 2018 and World Bank data, with evaluations and validations against historical data to ensure accuracy and reliability.
